qas.question: What kind of classification was subject to strict scrutiny?
What was the only situation in which a racial classification could be considered acceptable?

answers.text: necessary to promote a compelling governmental interest

qas.question: Who later confirmed that racial classifications were only to be upheld if they were necessary?
What is an example case that can help display where upholding a racial classification is beneficial?
What kind of classification was not subject to strict scrutiny?

plausible_answers.text: necessary to promote a compelling governmental interest

qas.question: What was the only situation in which a racial classification could be considered unacceptable?
Who later confirmed that racial classifications were only to be upheld if they were unnecessary?
What is an example case that can help display where upholding a racial classification is not beneficial?

context: In the beginning, <a0_0><b4_0>racial<b4_0/><a0_0/> classifications that identified race were inherently suspect and subject to strict scrutiny. These classifications would only be upheld if <a1_0><b5_0>necessary to promote a compelling governmental interest<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Later the <a2_0><b6_0>U.S. Supreme Court<b6_0/><a2_0/> decided that racial classifications that benefited underrepresented minorities were to only be upheld if necessary and promoted a compelling governmental purpose. (See <a3_0><b7_0>Richmond v. J.A. Croson Co<b7_0/>.<a3_0/>) There is no clear guidance about when government action is not "compelling", and such rulings are rare.
